discussion.content: From Google: The purpose of a separation pad is to introduce friction and separate the top sheet of paper from the remainder of the stack. This prevents multiple sheets of paper from being fed into the machine at one time.

comments.content: I guess it's because feed rollers just transfer the paper, if a single paper is pulled out from separation pad then there would be no issue. the problem started at separation pad.

questions.question_text:
A user notices a laser printer is picking up multiple sheets of paper from one of its paper trays. The problem started last week and has gotten worse.
Which of the following is MOST likely the cause of this problem?

discussion.content: Bluetooth is too slow for this. On the go cable (OTG) is basically a dongle (like USB C to USB 2.0) that you can use to transfer data to a flash drive and then to another phone

comments.content: I agree, I'm glad you posted this question, I didn't know USB OTG was a thing till now.

discussion.content: NFC is way too slow. OTC is too much of a hassle to get. I think Bluetooth is the correct answer.

Google search says "NFC requires much less power which makes it suitable for passive devices. But a major drawback is that NFC transmission is slower than Bluetooth (424kbit. second as compared to 2.1Mbit/seconds) with Bluetooth 2.1. One advantage that NFC enjoys is faster connectivity."

Bluetooth is definitely faster. However, I think the keywords here are applications and contact information. NFC connects faster and it is good enough for this use case. If we are transferring large amounts of data, Bluetooth would be the answer.

I think this is a bad question.
In my opinion, OTG is the correct answer given that it's "the only option that can MOVE large files" such as the applications QUICKLY!
NFC is 424 kbps at best. Bluetooth 2.0 is 3 Mbps and Bluetooth 4.0 is 25 Mbps. Bluetooth is readily available without needing to go purchase or order an OTG cable. This HAS GOT TO BE Bluetooth.
how is bluetooth slow for this is much faster than nfc

comments.content: I agree. Bluetooth is way faster compared to NFC but NFC is faster in establishing a connection compared to pairing bluetooth process. In the real world the best option will be BLUETOOTH

discussion.content: NFC works at about 400 kb/s how the heck is that the fastest solution to move ALL applications and data to your new mobile device? It would take days.

Correct answer: A & D
NFC and Bluetooth technologies both provide options for transferring data directly between devices that are held in close proximity to each other

questions.question_text:
A technician is upgrading a user's smartphone and wants to move all of the applications and contact information quickly to the new device.
Which of the following connection types would work BEST to do this?
Which of the following would provide power to an access point?

discussion.content:
A Power over Ethernet (PoE) injector is the most correct answer.
All other solutions do not provide power to other devices unless using PoE.

choices.B: Daylight savings time is not enabled.
choices.C: BIOS time is set to Universal Time Coordinated.
choices.A: The CMOS battery does not have a charge.
choices.D: The NTP server has gone offline.

discussion.content:
The dead CMOS battery is the most correct answer. A bad CMOS battery will fail to retain clock data and BIOS settings.
DST settings are not relevant to maintaining regular clock time.
BIOS time zones may default to UTC if the CMOS is bad but is itself not the cause.
An NTP server failure would not cause this one specific computer's clock to need resetting daily; multiple devices would be impacted and noted.

questions.question_text:
A user notices the system clock is changed every morning. The computer is shut down daily. A technician checks the time zone and finds it is correct, and then checks the BIOS settings and finds the time to be incorrect.
Which of the following is MOST likely the problem?

comments.content:
Sounds to me like they won't actually be managing the VM, just using it to write their code.

The organization offering the service is maintaining the VM, making this a Platform as a Service.

Most (if not all) cloud services will run on a vm somewhere, IAAS is just when you get to set up that VM for yourself instead of just getting access to what that VM does (PAAS or SAAS). As others have said the answer here is PAAS since the virtual machine will be used as a "platform" to develop code on.
VMs in the cloud is how I categorized IaaS too, but in the end, it said that developers were using the services, which makes the answer PaaS

discussion.content: I supposed VMs in the cloud is an example of Iaas.

questions.question_text: Virtual machines hosted in the cloud that are used by developers to code applications are an example of:
